INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette yesterday asked me a question, by leave, on the Internet. I thank her for giving me notice of that question, and I now respond to it. As senators will recall, the Senate resolved on 28 November 1995 that access to the Internet be provided to senators and members on request from 30 March 1996. On 29 November 1995 the Presiding Officers agreed to a joint proposal from the heads of the parliamentary departments on the respective role and responsibilities of each department in making access available.

INTERJECT.PARA: Planning for senators' and members' access to the Internet is well advanced. The parliamentary departments have made the necessary technical arrangements for connection to the Internet, including identification in principle of an Internet service provider and installation of the fire wall to guard against unauthorised access to the parliamentary network. However, funding for the costs of Internet usage by senators and members has not been finalised.

As honourable senators will probably be aware, Mr Speaker and I have been asked by the government to find substantial savings in the next financial year. Unfortunately, it is not possible to make such large reductions without affecting the level of services which can be provided to senators. In this context, there is concern about the possible open-ended nature of the costs and the appropriate source of funding for Internet access.

PARA.BREAK: I am advised by the Clerk of the Senate that funding the service from running costs is not consistent with the purpose of running costs appropriations nor with current financial stringencies facing the Department of the Senate. The service to be provided in relation to the Internet is in the nature of an entitlement provided under the Parliamentary Entitlements Act, which is similar to other entitle ments such as postage. Legal advice has been received in another context that entitlements under the Parliamentary Entitlements Act do not fall within the terms of running costs. It is preferable that all payments of entitlements under the act be made from special appropriations in the act, not from appropriations under appropriation acts.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am further advised by the clerk that the provision of computing equipment to senators in electorate offices is funded by the Department of Administrative Services from special appropriations. The funding of Internet access from Parliament House and electorate offices should be on the same basis, and the establishment of an entitlement under the Parliamentary Entitlements Act is the most appropriate way to proceed.

Consultation with the then Minister for Administrative Services was interrupted by the recent election and change of government. The Speaker and I have therefore written to the new Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) seeking his agreement to fund the recurrent cost of the service from special appropriations. In the interim, senators and their staff will continue to have access through the kiosk arrangements in the Senate wing and the Parliamentary Library.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking for the opposition on the supply bills, I would firstly like to make the point that this is a Friday sitting, a special arrangement entered into between the opposition, government and the other parties in the Senate in recognition of the cognisance of time to progress the government's legislation program.

SPEECH.PARA: When speaking today I will be making a number of points about the general economy, but I certainly will not be taking up my full time in recognition of the need to progress and expedite the government's legislation program. I indicate that is the approach of all of the Labor opposition speakers here today.

On the face of it the supply bills are routine machinery provisions enabling the business of government to be carried on until the passage of budget appropriations around November. By tradition supply bills provide the opportunity for wide ranging debate in this chamber. I intend to spend some time on a range of economic issues. The supply bills this year have special significance for a couple of reasons. The budget has been put back until August because of the election, and there is no disagreement between the government and the opposition on that. Therefore special provision has to be made for the funding of government until that time.

However, much more fundamentally and importantly this year we have a stark contrast between the pattern and scale of expenditure provided for under these bills based on continuity with the past—or should I say a discontinuity with the past—with the approach of the new government. The forthcoming budget bills will apparently present massive expenditure reductions. We do not support the supply bills with our usual enthusiasm this year for the reason I have just mentioned. We strongly believe that continuity with our forward estimates is a proper basis for the 1996‐97 budget, not the manic slash and burn approach proposed by the new government.

These bills provide an opportunity to expose at least some of the arguments that the government has been advancing in attempting to support what we believe is a fundamentally wrong headed, misguided and potentially disastrous budget strategy, not just in its effect on specific groups and constituencies who will be harmed and hurt by the cutbacks, but the whole Australian economy.

The government's approach is to argue a legacy of a black hole of an alleged $8 billion which allegedly reflects Labor's mismanagement. It argues that this constitutes a crisis for Australian economic policy. It has to be addressed as the absolute highest priority and any pain involved for particular groups will be outweighed by the wider gain for the Australian community. That is the government's basic premise.

Today I seek to contest some of those points in my contribution. We do not have a so‐called Beazley black hole. What we have is a Costello con designed to place blame on Labor for a number of reasons. The first is the Thatcherite small government ideology and the Fightback package which we believed to be dead and buried but which in fact was stored in the bottom drawer ready to be pulled out as soon as the government won the election. The second reason for this approach is the savings that the coalition must make in order to fund its own irresponsible unfunded election promises.

The issue of the $8 billion black hole has rapidly dwindled from the public psyche, certainly from the media's psyche, it seems to me, after talking to a number of financial reporters on Wednesday evening. The issue of this so-called $8 billion black hole is rapidly fading from sight with the publication of the ABS national account figures, which showed 4.8 per cent economic growth from the March quarter 1995 to the March quarter 1996. Compare that sort of growth rate with that of comparable countries in the OECD—at a time, I might emphasise, of very low inflation in Australia, in part contributed to by an appreciating Australian dollar, which has helped to keep inflation down, and also contributed to by the accord process. Legacies of this Labor government are: strong economic growth, strong employment growth, very low inflation, significant improvement in productivity, and significant improvement in research and development.

Even if there was an $8 billion deficit, we would argue that this does not constitute a crisis for the Australian economy or a failure of our economic management but rather is an outcome of our different approach and quite legitimate policy choices. Economic responsibility, from our point of view, demands a different policy approach. It is a policy approach that puts people first. It goes for growth now and in future and adopts a long time frame for addressing the deficit reduction. We acknowledge that that deficit reduction and the related issues that come from that deficit reduction must occur.

I make the point, as we have made it time and time again in debates in this chamber, that the so-called $8 billion black hole is not based on any calculation or accounting of what has happened in the past. It is a projection of what may happen in the future. It is not a blow-out. It is a Treasury official's guess—and I emphasise the word `guess'—based on past experience, past record and past economic outcomes about what will happen at some time in the future.

We will argue that this $8 billion is an exaggerated figure, rounded up, and a worst case scenario. The headline starting point next year is currently not $7.6 billion but $4.9 billion, and at least $2.3 billion of this is attributable to the negative actions of the coalition, the now government, in blocking a range of our budget measures in the Senate last year. Now the government has gone to great lengths to emphasise the opposition's obstruction since the election this year. Nothing could be further from the case.

To digress slightly, the Telstra bill and the industrial relations bill are off to committees for three months, but they are fundamental reforms of the industrial relations and telecommunications systems. It is not unreasonable that radical reforms should go to committees for three months for a thorough analysis. As I said earlier, we have attempted to progress the government's program by agreeing to exempt bills from the cut‐off that those opposite imposed on us when we were in government and we have endeavoured not to speak unnecessarily lengthily or repetitively. That stands in strong contrast to the approach of the now government when they were in opposition.

I mentioned some of the underlying themes of our approach, while we have been in opposition over the last couple of months, to the fundamental economic issues. There are a range of other points that I would like to comment on today, but I do not intend to do so, in consideration of the time factors that are before us. We want these supply bills passed today. We want to go on to other legislation. There are four or five other bills before us.

Before I conclude I would like to make one other contribution on something I have not touched on in any great detail. It is interesting to note in the contributions by Senator Short and others in speeches here and in question time that they emphasised the issue of savings and occasionally touched on the matter of superannuation.

I agree that one of the most fundamental issues we have to face—it is a fundamental problem; I will argue it is not a legacy of a Labor government—is this savings issue because without savings we do not have capital for investment. We then have to import capital in order to fund investment and for economic functioning. There is a whole range of issues associated with that. But a number of policy approaches that the government is proposing to take will directly reduce superannuation saving.

BREAK.PARA: In their election promises—and these may well be further promises they are going to abandon, but I will make a couple of quick points on this superannuation issue—the government committed to exempting employees earning under $900 a month from paying superannuation. Aside from the fact that the government will benefit because they will not have to ultimately contribute three per cent to those superannuation accounts, we are talking about a million Australians being exempted from superannuation. If you exempt a million Australians from superannuation payments, one of the critical factors is that that inevitably means less people and less money going into superannuation, and that must bring about a reduction in superannuation savings.

There are two other areas of change that will affect superannuation saving. One is the introduction of RSAs. By the government's own admission, RSAs will be a low return product. They recognise and accept that that is one of the outcomes. They are also arguing it is a low administration product. I take issue with that argument, but I will comment on that at another time.

The third approach to superannuation is to allow people to draw on superannuation for housing. Those three issues—exempting people with earnings less than $900 a month; allowing people to draw on superannuation for housing, and the introduction of RSAs—will reduce superannuation saving.

I notice that Senator Gibson is in the chamber. I urge Senator Gibson, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to read a recent publication called AMP Super Trends. I would urge you to look at the projected policy outcome of your approach to superannuation income with respect to savings. You may have legitimate arguments as to your policy approach in the areas I have mentioned for other reasons, but the effect on savings is very clear. I am not fond of quoting Access Economics, I have to say, but Access Economics make the same point. I do not wish to speak at length on this matter, but I do wish to draw it to the chamber's attention because governments have been very strongly pushing this issue of savings. I share their concern about the savings issue: it is a really fundamental and critical issue for this country.

In conclusion to my contribution to the supply debate, I would like to point out that, on the 4.8 per cent growth in the national account figures, whilst I think for everyone that figure was certainly on the high side, and was surprising, it certainly was not surprising to the opposition that the growth figure was high. Over our 13 years in government we ensured some fundamental reforms to the economy in a range of areas—micro‐economic reform, competition policy, waterfront reform, industrial relations reform and the reduction of tariffs.

I may say that the reduction in tariffs brought about—and I will have to double‐check the figure—$6 billion in lost revenue to the government as a consequence of tariffs. We hear a lot from the government about increases in revenue as a result of economic growth in the income tax area and the changes we have made to sales tax, capital gains tax, and fringe benefits tax, but we have lost significant revenue from the reductions in the tariff area.

I would like to make a point about the strong economic growth that Australia is experiencing. It is amongst the highest in the Western world, with extremely low inflation in comparison to most other countries. The background to this economic growth would have been far better if it had not been for two fundamental problems. Two sectors of the economy in particular have shown a pronounced weakness over the last two years. One is the agricultural sector and the other is finance and insurance. In both these sectors real output has declined at an average annual rate of 1.1 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively over the past 18 quarters. That is quite a staggering change in those two sectors. That reflects a number of issues. One is the collapse of world wool prices. The second is the recent severe drought in the case of agriculture.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does make a difference, a drought, does it?
—It does; drought makes a big difference.
—Let's go back to 1983.
—Order! Senator Panizza, you will have a chance to make a contribution later today.

—I notice Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran on the other side of the chamber. We all know—I certainly know from my travels as a parliamentary secretary into many of these drought areas—of the terrible effect of drought in the rural sector over the past two years.

BREAK.PARA: In the case of the finance and insurance sector, there has been a collapse in asset values over the last two to three years. If you exclude those two sectors from our economic growth rate over the last 4½ years, our economic growth rate has actually been about half a per cent per annum faster than historic norms. I wanted to make that point because it is not an issue that is debated often. We often debate the outcome of the horrific consequences of the drought and its effect and the collapse in wool prices.

Quite legitimately, Senator Boswell, Senator McGauran and others make the point that these hard times in the rural sector affect us all. It is not just people in rural and regional areas, as I have seen in the last 2½ years as a parliamentary secretary to Bob Collins and my travels in those areas. The collapse of the rural sector in many areas has dramatically affected the Australian economy. It affects us all. I want to pay tribute to people in rural and regional Australia who really have been battling in the last three or four years in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't like you.

—Senator McGauran, I suggest through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you talk to Senator Brownhill about whether country people, who have had experience in dealings with me, like me or not. I suggest you go and talk to the citrus industry, the pineapple industry, the sugar industry and a few other rural interest groups. I think you will get a surprise. I got a pleasant surprise in my dealings with them over a number of years.
—You are well liked.

—I will say modestly that we had a respect for our policy approaches in government. We could agree to disagree on many things, but it was a solid and constructive relationship. There are many other comments I would like to make about the economy but, as I have said, we have to give consideration to the government program. We would like to see these supply bills passed expeditiously and pass on to other business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, a report from the Commonwealth Ombudsman was released. The report relates to Telstra's conduct in releasing freedom of information documents in an arbitration process between Telstra and Ann Garms, one member of the group called CoT, casualties of Telecom—or Telstra, as it is now. The report is positively damning of Telstra's behaviour. It reports on what amounted to grossly unfair treatment, foul play and bad faith when it came to supplying claimants with essential information they needed for the arbitration procedure—information of which only Telstra had possession and which it tried, with every dirty trick in the book, to withhold from its opponents.

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra is a powerful taxpayer owned body that has used its disproportionate power to thwart, in every possible way, the casualties of Telstra from resolving their long running dispute by means of the `fast track arbitration process'. The Commonwealth Ombudsman's report slams Telstra for its approach in not releasing vital freedom of information material to its opponents in the arbitration process. Telstra has taken actions such as delaying and withholding vital information while at the same time providing it to its own solicitors, interpreting FOI requests so narrowly that it did not have to disclose information on the related telephone exchanges and limiting their interpretation to only information on services to the line; instructing its solicitors to apply exemptions wherever possible and that its solicitors screen for contentious issues, which is against the spirit of the act and against Telstra and government policy.

According to the former minister, as at September last year, Telstra had spent $5.7 million on its complaints system and, directly, $1.2 million just on the arbitration process of four CoT cases. I ask the Senate: how is any Australian able to participate in fair litigation with Telstra when it uses its financial might to crush any attempt by claimants to honour the arbitration agreement, as evidenced by the lengthy and thorough investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman?

This is not only the finding in relation to CoT member Ann Garms, but it is also supported by an earlier investigation into another CoT member, Graham Schorer. CoT members have been experiencing difficulties in Telstra phone services to their businesses for over 10 years. Telstra's behaviour has been the subject of many reports. Austel, the industry regulator, in a report calls Telstra `less than a model corporate citizen'. The Telecommunications Ombudsman said that the arbitration process had reached a new low-water mark in customer relations.

In November 1993, Senator Alston and I were told by Telstra that there was no need for a Senate inquiry; it assured us that a fast track non-legalistic process could be set up that would also facilitate access to FOI documents, and that it would be all over by April 1994. After similar assurances from Telstra to CoT members, a fast track settlement proposal was signed by four CoT members in November 1993 in the belief that Telstra was committed to a speedy non-legalistic process that would facilitate access to Telecom documents under FOI.

It was actually no less a person than the chairman of Austel who lodged Mrs Garms's FOI application with Telstra in December 1993. To this day, 2½ years later, Mrs Garms is still being drip fed some documents and still being denied access to exchange documents. Telstra is maintaining to the Ombudsman that arbitration is not an appropriate way for the claimants to obtain FOI information, despite the process underlying both the settlement and arbitration arrangements.

The CoT cases did not want to go through arbitration; they much preferred the settlement process. However, Telstra pushed for arbitration. An e-mail between Mr Blount and Steve Black of Telstra obtained under FOI, said:

BREAK.PARA: My course is therefore to force the arbitrator to rule on our preferred rules of arbitration.

It continued by reading, `We are only remaining in there because to walk away would appear to lead directly to a Senate inquiry.' The CoT members clearly had the understanding that Telstra wanted arbitration or they would not take part at all.

The CoT members signed up for arbitration because it was guaranteed to be fast track and non-legalistic and that FOI documents would be facilitated under the arbitration process. It is now 2½ years later. They have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal, technical and accountancy fees to counter the extremely legalistic and technical approach Telstra has forced on the arbitration process.

There is a second tier of casualties of Telstra. One of the members of this second tier received an arbitration determination last week that barely covered the hundreds of thousands of dollars spent in fees. It is Telstra which has made the process so legalistic. Now the Ombudsman has confirmed, in yesterday's report, that Telstra has adopted all sorts of delaying tactics and has withheld vital documents, preventing fair and equal access by the CoT members to the final arbitration process.

Telstra not only signed an agreement with the CoT members for a fast-track, non-legalistic process that would deliver FOI documents to the claimants but also promised the now Minister for Communications and the Arts and me that it would be fast track, non-legalistic and would facilitate FOI. The Ombudsman has recommended compensation for the defective administration of Telstra in the processing of the FOI documentation.

But the issue is far more serious than that. The report details instance after instance of Telstra's actions being directed at frustrating the claimants in the arbitration process. The Ombudsman has said that it is wrong for Telstra to direct that their solicitors identify whether exceptions have been applied `wherever possible' under the FOI act; their record-keeping practice relating to matters which were in dispute was inadequate; it was unreasonable for Telstra to unilaterally scope down the FOI applications so as to not disclose any documents of the relevant Fortitude Valley telephone exchange; and Telstra remained orientated to avoiding disclosure of information, and a change of culture and practice was necessary.

Mr Acting Deputy President Calvert, I am sure you will agree that they are scathing remarks about the behaviour of Telstra. All these findings, and more, are unacceptable for a corporate citizen like Telstra. The open-ended ability of Telstra to finance legal and technical challenges and raise the goalpost so high for small business people, who have in some cases already lost their businesses through lack of telephone services, is totally unacceptable.

The saga for the CoT members has gone on far too long. The long, drawn‐out dispute, without apparent end, has worn them down emotionally and financially. The delays caused by Telstra, now so clearly documented in the Ombudsman's report, have made a farce of the fast‐track arbitration process promised to the CoT members and promised to Senator Alston and me.

Clearly, a means to end Telstra's conduct in relation to FOI documents has to be found. But as the procedure now stands, Telstra has made it so bogged down in legalistic and technical demands that the fast‐track process has turned into a nightmare and a quagmire for the parties on the other side of Telstra's might. I welcome the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report. I congratulate her office on a thorough and professional report, but this matter cannot continue to lie where it is now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but I do need to raise a matter which is of fundamental importance to this parliament and, indeed, of fundamental importance to democracy. It is about the actual attempt to reduce substantially the funding for the Senate and, indeed, for other parliamentary departments as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the pieces of legislation we are dealing with at the moment is the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. I want to indicate to the Senate that we in this parliament have reached a watershed: we are either going to allow the executive government, of whatever colour, to dictate the terms under which we carry out our function; or we stand up as we are required to stand up, as members of parliament, as an institution, for the protection of parliamentary democracy in Australia.

I want to indicate to the Senate that the government has requested a two per cent reduction in the running costs of the Senate and the parliamentary departments. In fact, in its forward estimates of 1996-97, the Department of Finance has applied the two per cent reduction to the Senate's running costs base. This results in an estimated provisional running costs reduction of about $918,000. The Senate, in running costs alone, will be a million dollars worse off than we were last year—a million dollars. I ask the Senate to consider that.

It is an attack on our ability to perform our fundamental tasks as a house of review. We are a house of review and, in order to exercise that function, I believe we are required to examine legislation as it comes from the House of Representatives—in effect, as it comes from the executive government—in a manner that does justice to those measures.

If the government were to stop and think, it would understand that it is in its best interests—in the government's best interests—to ensure that that scrutiny and review is properly undertaken for each and every measure that is presented to us. Why? Because otherwise the system will be run by the bureaucrats. The bureaucrats would be absolutely happy if this chamber was out of the road. It gets in their way. It is a problem.

But, of course, we do not have a dictatorship—not yet; we have a democracy where people are required to exercise a vote. What do they vote for? They vote for the parliament. Are we going to allow those votes to be despoiled because of an attempt to castrate, to a certain extent, our legitimate activities?

I now want to give you the example of the committee system of the Senate. The committee system of this Senate has been operating quite efficiently and effectively over quite a long period of time. The committee system of the Senate enables an in‐depth review of particular legislation referred to committees. It enables the public to have an input in a direct sense into the deliberations of this chamber.

Committees are established by this Senate. When references or bills are referred to those committees, very often there is widespread advertising of that fact and a call for submissions from the public, who come to the committees and present their submissions to senators who are members of the particular committee. The members of that committee are then able to ask questions of the submittees about their submissions, about particular aspects of the bill or about particular aspects of the reference.

This is all part of our representative function. We in this chamber have at least two functions. One function is a representative function; namely, the requirement to express the views of electors in this place, in the committee system and through committee reports. Another function we have is the review function, as I have mentioned before.

Very often select committees need to be established. In fact, one select committee met last night for the first time since it was reconstituted after the election. That was the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, which is dealing with questions about the adequacy of guidelines for film and television programs. It is a very important committee, one which I am sure will attract a considerable amount of attention and one which I am sure will attract a large number of submissions over a period of time. We are sitting only until 31 December and we have to report before that date.

There are a number of other select committees. In respect of those committees, there was a review undertaken last year by the Senate and the Department of Finance. The review was entitled `Senate Committee Office: Review of Resources' of July 1995. Bear in mind that this was a joint review by the executive, which is represented by the Department of Finance, and by the Department of the Senate. One of the recommendations of that review was:
that select committee activity—
that is, Senate select committee activity—

BREAK.PARA: over and above that agreed to be catered for in the running costs base by the permanent inclusion of 104 weeks of select committee funding per annum, would be funded in accordance with the agreed profiles in Attachment 1 of the Review .
This was an agreed document. It gave a degree of certainty in respect of one of our functions; that is, the function which is exercised through select committees.

What has happened? The Department of Finance has unilaterally repudiated that agreement. I believe that—and I say this through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the parliamentary secretary who is dealing with this debate—should not be countenanced. I believe the executive government should have a very serious look at the repudiation by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) of that particular agreement. I note that Minister Fahey has not repudiated it, but it is perfectly clear that his department has. I believe that is a matter of grave concern not only for this chamber but also for the executive government. How can any member of parliament have faith or trust in a bureaucracy which unilaterally repudiates such an agreed position?

I know we are in a situation of economic stringency. Everybody has to play their part. I believe that this Senate is being asked to play more than its part. What I indicate is that not only has the Department of Finance repudiated the agreement, which was necessary to give some certainty to the operations of the select committee process and the committee processes in this particular Senate, not only has it demanded a two per cent across-the-board reduction in the costs of all departments—and it is understood by us that something like that needs to be done—but it is seeking an additional saving of a further $10 million across the parliamentary departments.

So, Mr Acting Deputy President, I appeal through you to the government to have a good look at that. I think it is in the government's own best interests that this chamber perform its functions of review. I think it is very important because, as I indicated before, if it does not do that, then the place is just run by bureaucrats. I do not want anyone to run away with the idea that I believe all bureaucrats are bad; I do not. There are many thousands of very dedicated public servants in this country, but there are also a few who would like to clip the wings of the parliament and, in so doing, despoil our democracy.

This is a fundamental issue. Although I have examples of what members of the current government said in regard to the Senate when they were in opposition, I do not think quoting those and making this a political issue would assist at all. I hope the parliamentary secretary would take this matter through to the relevant authorities in the executive government in the expectation that we will be able to have the necessary wherewithal to perform properly our functions in the interests not only of good government but also of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The parliament today is cognately debating the supply bills. These are bills which, had we been elected to government, would have come forward in a way similar to the way they have come forward under this government and they are in order to provide sufficient finance for the wheels of government services to continue to turn until such time as the budget can be brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: The new government will obviously put its stamp upon the face of the Australian economy with the new budget. What is happening between now and then is, in essence, where the law has not been changed, a continuity of what we have been doing, and that will continue up until the new budget. So there is support on this side of the house for these bills. Indeed, to contemplate not giving supply would be a serious issue and is one in which we have set out our principal position on the record many times.

However, the bills we are debating do reflect the outcome of the 1995-96 budget and therefore ought to be viewed from the perspective of a model for what should go forward in the 1996-97 budget. What we are seeing and what I want to address my remarks to today is an artificial crisis that is being created by the government—not a real crisis; a crisis of confidence, however, in the economy—and the argument that there needs to be a savage slash of government expenditure, indeed, in my memory, the most ruthlessly savage slash of government expenditure that has been proposed by a government. I do not believe that is true. This is a political argument, not an economic one. In my remarks this morning I wish to expose the hypocrisy of the government's position.

Before I turn to the body of my remarks, I want to acknowledge the address just given to the Senate by Senator Harradine. He touched on a fundamental point and it goes to principles long ago established as enduring and permanent in a modern democracy, and that is the sanctity of the parliamentary process and the separation of that process from the executive.

I have had views not always the same as Senator Harradine on the precise application of those principles, but one area on which I stand square with him, shoulder to shoulder, is that the funding to the parliamentary process should be carved out of a normal appropriation situation so that the government cannot interfere with it and thus undermine the functioning of the parliament and its ability to scrutinise the executive. That ought to be and has to be a fundamental principle and I endorse what Senator Harradine has said about that today.

Let me start the body of my remarks, however, by saying that no-one disputes that a government has the obligation, in the taxpayers' and electors' interest, to run a tight fiscal ship. Flabby government expenditure and inefficient application of government programs are not what governments are put in office to do. They are put in office to ensure that they run a very tight fiscal ship and administer the affairs of state efficiently.

I want to make the point that, when we were in government, we did that. We did it not just on the basis of bean counting—that is, what is the cost—but also on the basis of quality and equity. It is a question of the quality of services and not just the cost of those services. It is a question of the equitable distribution of the taxpayers' dollar laundered through the government and filtered through its programs that is the important question here. I want to mark the spot where we did that; we are not going to retreat from it. Our record is a fine one although we are pilloried and criticised for political purposes. Objectively, when the history of our period of government is written, I think the truth of my remarks will be found to be the case.

At the moment, what we are seeing is not a strategy for a budget; it is not an economic debate. What we are now seeing is a political debate and a political strategy, and the political purpose of the strategy is ideological—it is to impose in Australia a Thatcherite approach to economic management and a Thatcherite approach for smaller government. Under the cover of the allegation of an $8 billion black hole, this current government is embarking, as I have said, on the most savage slash and burn of the Australian economy that we have seen. Every program is on the block to be cut down and destroyed.

Once you cut the finances out of these programs to below critical mass you actually bring about their destruction. The purpose is not economic or fiscal rectitude. The purpose is to shrink the size of the public sector so that it performs not the equity balancing role that it should—helping those in less protected positions in society—but, rather, an elite role, thus creating the `have' and `have not' structure that we have seen bedevil Britain, and which currently bedevils the US and other countries that do not direct their attention to an equitable social agenda. It is, as I have said, ideological and Thatcherite. No budget strategy would be based on such a flimsy foundation as this one is. It is a flimsy foundation in the sense that an estimate provided in March this year suggested—I underline the word `estimate'—what the deficit would be in August, if nothing else changed.

It is the raison d'etre for what is being invited—what Mr Costello has called the Beazley $8 billion black hole, what the Canberra Times earlier this week called the illusory black hole, and what the AAP wire dubbed, on Wednesday, after the national accounts for March were published, the mythical black hole. The government maintains there is a black hole. The media says that this is a joke. The media is right; the government is wrong—there is not a black hole at all. The allegation of an $8 billion black hole is on an estimate, if no parameter changed between now and the budget. And, of course, those parameters have changed, and changed quite significantly.

It is very important that this point be tied down so that all of those concerned groups in Australian society, worried about the slash and burn approach of this government to the programs and funding that support them, understand that it is built on a fraud. There is no expenditure which can be traced which will lead to this. There is no calculation or accounting to prove this has happened—no expenditure for a blow‐out.

I will come back to the `if nothing changed' scenario, but I also want to say that it is a worst case scenario. The actual figure of the deficit at present is $4.9 billion, and $2.3 billion of that is due to the coalition, who are now the government, knocking back in the last budget bills which would have generated $2.3 billion. So they, too, have played a hand in generating a deficit here.

I return to the point. This is a political approach. You would not approach a budget this way. The way in which you would approach a normal budget calculation is to produce a range of figures to show what various estimates would be and continue to update those figures as new information on economic performance comes to hand. You would not base yourself on a worst case scenario. You would base yourself on the probable case scenario, and you would develop that. You would identify a savings ballpark figure. You would then look at where efficiencies and better targeting of measures could save money before you cut the heart out of any programs. You would then identify your own expenditure.

The government made some extravagant promises during the election campaign. We did not; they did. Part of their own expenditure has to be accommodated here. You would not engage in wholesale cuts. You would start to balance the effectiveness of programs and talk to the portfolio ministers, asking them to produce savings without cutting the heart out of the effectiveness of what they are doing.

BREAK.PARA: That has not been the government approach on this occasion. The government has sought to artificially create a sense of crisis. There is no crisis in the economy. The Australian economy is sound. The most recent evidence we had of that is the phenomenally good growth figure of 4.8 per cent in the national accounts for March published just this week. The pundits argue—they argued this in the first quarter of the year—that the economy is expected to perform very strongly in the second half of 1996, and it will.

But if the government gets its way and brings down a horror budget, as it foreshadows, then it will have cut the heart out of public investment in the economy, it will have withdrawn expenditure from the economy and it will bring on a mini recession so that the growth and potential the economy has will not be realised; in fact, it will be reversed. Nonetheless, on current settings, the forecast is for a strong performance in the second half of the year.

This is not a real crisis; it is a politically created cover story to justify an ideological purpose. The cuts foreshadowed across the board do not have to be made in the way in which they are being made. Every sector in Australia will be affected, whether it be the vice‐chancellors, the higher education people, the people in education, the people in health and community services, the people who provide medical services to Australia, the people in welfare or welfare recipients, or whether it be the people in business and industry who are supported by trade incentives—across the board.

The ABC is facing a massive slashing. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and Worksafe Australia, which has lowered the level of industrial accidents in Australia, will now be cut; thus, I think, increasing the possibility of a bigger loss of production to industry because accidents will now rise without the supervising responsibility of that agency, and so it goes.

PARA.BREAK: All of those sectors of the Australian community should protest very loudly because what is being worked here is a scam. There are two levels to the scam. One level is the panic and the artificial crisis that the govern ment has created over the $8 billion black hole. The other level is the determination to bring in a budget that does not quite realise the darkest fears that they have excited in the minds of the community so that on budget night there will be a collective sigh of relief. It is like saying, `The house burnt down but at least I saved my furniture and kids.' It is that sort of saving, that sort of relief. The intention then, in engendering that false relief, is to try to get away with saying, `It wasn't as bad as we thought it would be. Therefore, we can live with it.' Nonetheless, you have lost your house at the end of the day. That is the type of scam that is being worked here.

BREAK.PARA: My reason for intervening and speaking in this debate today is to point out to all of the pressure groups in Australia that if you do put pressure on this government it will back down. It did back down just this week. We saw on Saturday in New South Wales a number of by-elections. In one seat, Clarence, we saw a swing to Labor of 14.3 per cent and the taking of that seat off the National Party. As soon as that occurred, on Monday evening in a speech to the National Farmers Federation, John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia, backed away from one of the areas he was going to cut. He said to the NFF that the diesel fuel rebate scheme—wink, wink; nod, nod—would be okay. And he said that the other issue the NFF was concerned about, the 150 per cent tax deduction for rural research and development—wink, wink; nod, nod—would be okay.

That proves that this government will go weak at the knees with political pressure. They are going to retreat a tad from the scare campaign they have put in order to get the electoral bounce they want. The advice I have for every pressure group is: if you don't speak up loudly enough then you will get cut, but if you do speak up loudly enough and put your pressure on the government where it counts then you might succeed, as the National Farmers Federation have done, and have your program saved in some way. I think that is very important. I think it is very important because there is room for savings.

Let me just go back to this so-called $8 billion black hole, remembering that that is only the case if nothing changes. I will quote Professors John Nevile and Fred Gruen and Mr Fred Argy, who in the Australian Financial Review on 20 May made this point:
. . . the figure of $8 billion is itself not a firm figure. It is a Treasury forecast assuming no policy changes and a rate of growth of the economy of 3.25 per cent.
They go on:
. . . a small difference in the assumed rate of economic growth can make a large difference in the size of the projected deficit.

Remember the figure of 3.25 per cent. If nothing changed and we had a rate of economic growth of 3.25 per cent, then maybe the $8 billion would be there. That is the point. The quarterly accounts for March that were published this Tuesday show that the rate of economic growth was 4.8 per cent. That is a level more than one per cent higher than the one that the $8 billion deficit is forecast on.

A significant parameter has changed. A significant facility is in the hands of the government not to cut as they have forecast. I again repeat to all of the interested parties out there: if you don't put pressure on them, then you won't get your share of these savings. They do act politically. They did just this week when pressure from the farm lobby centred on them. So get in for your chop or you will get chopped out. That is the bottom line, given the performance of this government.

In the last few minutes available to me, I will make another point. We are seeing the guts cut out of industry support provisions by this government. We are seeing the dominance in government thinking of a scorched earth, ultra‐dry economic approach—a belief that industry in the post‐protectionist era needs no support at all. That is, of course, not true. Industry, rightly, has pointed out that it is not true.

I do not support—I never did and as a former industry minister would not anyway—a handout mentality. The government I was a part of conducted a major restructuring of the Australian economy and wound back tariffs and integrated the Australian economy into the economy of the world.

In a post‐protectionist economy in Australia there is a very important role for industry policy. That is not a handout policy and a protective policy, but it is a policy of providing at the export end international market intelligence through Austrade so that Australian business can see into every other market in the world and identify opportunity for itself. It is a policy of providing some support for Australian business people to venture into those markets and win contracts. The export market development scheme, the DIFF scheme and the ITA scheme are there for that purpose.

It is a policy, too, where people have initiative and are making a play to grow their companies, of providing through the NIE scheme to help them do so. It is a policy that provides incentives for research and development. It is a policy that particularly helps small to medium sized enterprises be across those things that they do not have an economy of scale to do in-house, that can be provided as a service to the sector so that those with initiative—this is not picking winners; this is backing winners—can be supported to achieve. If they do achieve, they create jobs in Australia, they grow the Australian economy and they turn the current account deficit around.

To cut out in one fell swoop, as this government is proposing, all of those programs which support and back that initiative is to in fact cut out the job creation that growth in the business sector will create, to in fact turn the current account deficit back on itself and blow that out. It is a wrong headed, ultra‐dry, Thatcherite policy that has no place in post‐protectionist Australia. If this government goes go down that road, it will be dudding Australian industry and Australian workers who are looking for employment in the future. It is as simple as that.

My final concern is a scientific issue. The astronomy community is concerned about the withdrawal of negotiations with the European Southern Observatory. As a former science minister, I asked the department to negotiate a role for Australia in the construction and operation of that telescope. It is important that astronomers in Australia—a major sector of our science achievement in this country—have access to that operation and that there be a longer term vision for astronomy. In the election campaign the present government promised to support them. It is now saying, `Withdraw from the negotiations, you can't proceed.' That is going back on a firm and sober election undertaking, and it should not have occurred. The fact that it has occurred is a travesty, and the government should reverse its position. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1996, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1996-97 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1996-97, which are being dealt with together, I want to try to put some context into the debate. Australia is a low tax country. When we compare Australia to OECD countries, we find that Australia does not require individuals to pay a large portion of their income in tax. Australians most certainly pay more tax than people in countries with no social security. Australians most certainly pay more tax than people in countries with governments which do not believe they have a role to look after equity and access in education and in health, or to provide some guarantee that people will not starve in the streets. So, in effect, Australia is a small government country. Therefore, why is there evidence of a strong ideological agenda to push for smaller government and smaller tax?

SPEECH.PARA: Let's face it, there are always two sides to any government spending agenda. You work out what funds you are going to need for the programs you want, and you work out how you are going to fund them. There seems to be an overall emphasis on cutting back on the amount of tax paid by people and businesses in Australian society, and therefore we get an overemphasis on cutting back the programs. We do not seem to have an emphasis on the questions: what are we trying to achieve as a country; and, what do we think the role of government is?

I have a different opinion than the government has. The Greens stand for four principles: environmental sustainability, peace and disarmament, social justice, and participatory democracy. My belief is that governments have an a very important role to see that there is a distributive justice in the availability of such things as health and education, and even the ability to have a decent, safe transport system. We seem to have an almost unstated assumption that, for example, our transport system—our rail transport system, air systems, airlines and shipping—must be run not only by private enterprise but also by very large international conglomerates. I am not sure where this comes into logic. The irony is that in recent times we have heard a lot said about political correctness, when perhaps we should be talking more about economic correctness.

What we hear as the norm now from many commentators when talking about not just the economy but how the social system should run is what was a recognised ideological stance back in 1980s. It was then called monetarism and was the work of Milton Freidman. There were certain assumptions associated with that ideology. It was said the market was the answer to all our problems. It was claimed that you could go to a school or university using a voucher system and that that was your a choice, but it forgot to mention that you had a choice to starve. It said you had the right not to pay many taxes, but it also said that you had the right to go to a poor house if you did not fit into the system.

Basically, what was recognised as an ideological economic choice in the 1980s has suddenly become economic correctness. Anybody who speaks differently to that and talks about a value system that does not fit the economic correctness mode is now considered to be a radical. The changes that have occurred in the last few years are probably some of the most radical that this country has ever seen—for example, the changes that have resulted from globalism and internationalism and the changes that have resulted from the assumption that everything that government must do must conform somehow to competition policy and if it does not there has to be a specific exception made for it in legislation.

I cannot see that this place is going to make exceptions in all of the areas where we thought there was some value, apart from the short‐term dollar. I am very afraid for this country. I am very afraid about what is going to happen by 1998 when the competition time bomb explodes.

In the last few days, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has been using the current account figures to justify slashing the budget further. It seems that he has conveniently ignored the demise of the twin deficit theory—that is, that there is no provable connection between the budget and the current account. Certainly you cannot guarantee to improve your current account by further slashing and burning and yet this is what is coming from the Treasurer. He is ignoring completely that in 1993 we signed the Uruguay Round of GATT. He is ignoring people like the Greens who, in 1993, said, `Look at the trade deficit in a year or two years time.'

Let us have a look at what the current account deficit will be once the government takes the very large steps—those steps which were not actually required under the rules of the World Trade Organisation but which Australia chose to take to pretend to be pure and so that the rest of world would follow—it intends to take. How naive!

Surprise, surprise! Here we are in 1996 with a growing current account deficit and a growing trade blow‐out, which, funnily enough, started just after the decision to join the World Trade Organisation. From then on the deficit increased by $1 billion or $2 billion a month. Before that we had, almost from time immemorial, a trade surplus. What a surprise.

How on earth do you think we are going to improve the trade surplus by slashing our budget in Australia further? There might be some slight changes, but it might go in other direction. Instead of admitting that our trade regime—our tariff regime and our industry policy—is having a major effect on our balance of trade and our trade figures, we are pretending it only has something to do with the amount we have to slash and burn on government departments.

While speaking about slashing and burning on government departments, I will say that the Greens did give notice to the government that during the committee stage of this bill we will be asking questions about these bills, about the measures in these bills. So far I have largely seen one adviser from the government. I hope the rest are listening in because I expect sufficient people will participate in this debate during the committee stage and ask questions about the nature of these bills.

It is only reasonable to expect that the answers will be provided in the committee stage. Therefore, if answers are not provided perhaps we will need to adjourn the debate until the answers are available. But I would expect that, having given notice that we would like to ask questions about what is in these bills, you would provide the people to answer the questions.

The doctrine of economic correctness has been criticised by people such as Robert Fitzgerald from ACOSS. The frightening thing is that it is simply no longer an economic doctrine. If you think about economic correctness as it is now writ, it now permeates every public sector. It permeates education; it permeates health; it permeates women's issues and Aboriginal issues; it permeates communication; it permeates industrial relations. It permeates every section.

Economic correctness not only is the short‐term dollar profitability of major corporations—now considered to be the major driving force of the economy—but it is now the major driving force of how we make decisions on the rest of our society; never mind that the outcome of this level of competition policy actually means that we may well be destroying community, that the casualties of this system may end up costing government a great deal more.

Unfortunately, the system looks at what areas appear to be superfluous. Those kinds of areas are community support mechanisms. Funnily enough, very shortly down the track you will find that if you pull out the community support mechanisms the cost does not decrease. The most effective, most efficient ways to provide support in our community are through community support mechanisms. Once you pull those out and community starts to erode and be destroyed, the costs of rampant individualism soar. The costs of alienation, the costs of people falling out of system and falling along the way, become greater. There are the human costs, the environmental costs and the social costs.

That leads me to the question: what is radical and what is commonsense? The question the Greens have been asking, certainly since I have been talking on Green economic issues since 1993, is: what are the outcomes of the changes that have been made so far and what are the prospective outcomes of the changes that you are proposing from now on? That is not a radical question.

That is the kind of question the Australian Consumers Association is asking, and that is not radical either. It says if you want a new trade regime, if you have a new trade regime, if you have signed onto the Uruguay Round of GATT, let us find out what the implications are. What are the environmental implications? What are the social implications? What are the employment and other economic implications? I have not seen any report that actually indicates that the government has made the effort to find out what they are. Yet we are prepared to jump not only into the Uruguay Round of GATT but also into APEC without even assessing what we have done so far.

Let us look at what the implications are of competition policy. What are the impacts on the people you are serving? What are the impacts on the level of youth health? What are the impacts on the quality of education? What are the impacts on communities able to service their needs? What are the impacts on women? What are the impacts on Aboriginal people? What are the impacts on the environment when during competition policy you say that the most important thing is the dollar, and the short‐term dollar at that? We are not even prepared to look at the long-term implications of destroying our natural capital in the meantime.

These are not radical questions; these are basic questions. If you are operating a basic business and making a policy change, you would check out what the implications were of making those decisions. I am very afraid for the policy direction of Australia because we have not asked those questions and I have seen no indication that we have made any attempt to look at the answers. The policy outcomes remain to be seen in terms of real outcomes.

In concluding my speech I have a number of questions I would like to ask during the committee stage about the decisions that have been made which are indicated in the bills before us. I will be expecting that there will be the ability to find answers to those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I am referring to the funding for the Office of the Status of Women and the national agenda for women. It has been foreshadowed that there will be budget cuts to the Office of the Status of Women which will bring about a 46 per cent reduction in the staffing levels of that department. These cuts will also affect the national agenda for women and all those volunteer women's groups funded in some small way through that program. There is every indication that those cuts will be extraordinarily bloodthirsty in their effect.

A number of these groups have met with the responsible minister, Senator Newman, as was indicated yesterday, but these groups have not been provided with any sort of reassurance or assistance whatsoever. These bills before the Senate today allow for the funding of the business of government until the budget appropriation bills can go through. This interim funding that is meant to carry us through from 30 June until the budget is not applied to every government program and certainly not applied to every organisation funded by government. The groups which have been clearly excluded from this process of continuing funding are those funded through the women's agenda and the Office of the Status of Women.

These are groups which, through extraordinarily small amounts of funds provided by the government and an extraordinarily large amount of voluntary labour from women all over Australia, continue work that is very beneficial for the community at large and certainly very much appreciated by women individually.

There are a number of others that I will not mention, but that is a sample to show the mainstream nature of these women's groups and the contribution that they make to the community at large.

I have been very lucky to have been involved with the Older Women's Network at Gosford. From time to time they have invited me along. It is a gathering point for women, particularly women of retirement age, for swapping information and taking in new ideas from outside. It has been an extraordinarily useful organisation and very much appreciated by that community. In fact, about 25 per cent of people in the Central Coast seat of Robertson are over 50. I wish to put on the record today my deep concern, and the concern of a number of groups who have raised the matter with me, that these groups have not been provided with funding up until the budget through resourcing appropriated in these supply bills, and I hope that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman, may reconsider and allow the very useful organisation of services provided by that funding to continue.

If you go out and ask people in small, medium or big businesses whether any of them have had a 30 per cent increase in revenue over the last four years, very few people put up their hands. State governments have not had that increase. But the Commonwealth government has.

In addition to spending that, they also went out and borrowed. As at 30 June 1991, five months before Mr Keating became Prime Minister, Commonwealth debt stood at $32 billion. Today it is virtually $100 billion. So over the almost five-year period, another $60-odd billion was borrowed on the Australian market, and they spent that. In addition, in the same four‐year period, some of the silver was sold off. The total of $8.7 billion from the sale of Qantas, half the Commonwealth Bank, CSL and a few smaller bits and pieces has been spent also. In addition, back in the mid- 1980s, about eight per cent of Commonwealth outlays went into infrastructure. It was investment in the future. By the time Mr Keating became Prime Minister in December 1991, that figure was down to about 4.7 per cent. It dropped even further, so that this current financial year it is actually a negative figure—minus 2.3 per cent.

Every household knows that you cannot spend beyond your income. You cannot sell off the house to pay for the groceries. If you do, you end up in trouble. That is exactly what happened with the previous government. That is why we are in a mess. The previous government also fudged the figures by not changing the financial reporting standards. The coalition made a commitment before the election that it was going to change the financial reporting standards and move to accrual accounting. That will separate the assets and liabilities—in other words, the balance sheet items or the house items—and the operating expenses, the groceries. By doing that, it will then be plain to everybody what has really happened to the Commonwealth's finances.

The previous government did a very poor job and left us with a great debt, which we have to rein in. We have been living beyond our means and that is why we have Treasury's estimate, not the government's estimate, of an $8 billion deficit. The supply bills are machinery bills so that the business of government can continue for the next five months. On behalf of the government, I thank all honourable senators for their contributions in this debate this morning. I have covered a wide range of matters in my response.

Statement of reasons for introduction and passage in 1996 winter sittings
Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996
Purpose of proposed bill
The proposed Bill will make amendments to the provisions in the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) relating to the Migration Agents Registration Scheme (MARS).

MARS was established to provide consumer protection for visa applicants from unscrupulous and/or incompetent migration agents. The scheme's main elements are to act as a register of agents and assess their proficiency, and to administer and enforce a legally binding code of conduct to guide agents in their business activities.
The proposed amendments will ensure that MARS can continue beyond 21 September 1996.
Reasons for introduction and passage in 1996 winter sittings

Subsection 333(1) of the MARS provisions contains a statutory sunset provision which will automatically terminate the entire scheme on 21 September 1996. The sunset provision was originally designed to allow MARS to run for an initial three years (until September 1995) but was extended for one year by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act (No. 5) 1995. The one year extension to allow time for the JSCM to report on the operation of MARS and for the government to make a considered response.

To enable MARS to continue after 21 September 1996, it is essential that the migration act be amended before that date. Legal advice indicates that it will not be possible to revive the existing registration scheme if the sunset clause is not amended before 21 September 1996 and that it may be necessary to refund substantial sums which have been paid as migration agent registration fees.

It is intended that the scheme be extended for one year. This will allow a further review of the scheme with particular emphasis on the possibility that it might be replaced by enhanced self‐regulation.
Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Amendment Bill
Statement of reasons for introduction and passage in the 1996 winter sittings

Under the provisions of the Act, parliamentary pensions are fixed as a percentage of parliamentary salaries payable to serving members from time to time. This includes the additional pensions payable for service as a minister, which are fixed as a percentage of the additional salaries payable to current ministers.

The reduction in the additional salary for non‐cabinet ministers, with effect from 11 March 1996, could have had the effect of reducing the accrued benefits of certain scheme members, including the pensions of former members, and spouses of deceased former members, where the members held office as non‐cabinet ministers.

The bill will prevent a decrease in accrued parliamentary pension entitlements resulting from the new ministerial salary arrangements. Provisions in the Bill have retrospective commencement from 2 March 1996, thus necessitating introduction of the Bill and its passage in the winter sittings.
Delay in dealing with the bill would result in overpayments being made to certain parliamentary pensioners.
Customs Amendment Bill 1996
Statement of reasons for introduction and passage during the 1996 winter sittings

This bill implements the changes to the tariff concession system in part XVA of the Customs Act 1901, foreshadowed in December 1995. It also provides for the revocation of all concession instruments written to policy by‐law items 43, 45, 46, 52 and 56 of schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 which was announced by the government on 8 May 1996.

The bill is intended to achieve the revenue savings announced in December 1995, which are scheduled to commence from 1 July 1996. This can only be attained by the consideration of this bill in the current sittings of parliament. Further, by allowing the revocation of policy by‐law concessional instruments proposed in the bill, this measure will ensure that necessary administrative restructuring of the policy by‐law system occurs.

If this bill is not dealt with in these sittings, the government's revenue target will not be achieved, and consideration may need to e given to other budgetary savings to ensure that the budget deficit is eliminated within the two year period announced.
Delay will also create uncertainty in the business community, where the expectations are that the changes will be in place on 1 July this year, as announced.

The need for early amendments to the tariff concession system was anticipated, but the intervention of the election and announcements of further changes to the tariff concession system during the election period, to a large extent addressed in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, prevented earlier action being taken.
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996
Statement of reasons for introduction and passage during the 1996 winter sittings
This bill represents the outcome of initiatives arising from the announcements made in the context of the 1996 federal election.

The bill gives effect to the Customs Tariff duty rate changes announced on 8 May 1996. The bill removes item 11 of schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act 1995, which is now redundant. It changes from `free' to `3%' the concessional duty rate applying to Tariff Concession Orders under part XVA of the customs act (as delivered by items 19 and 50 of schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act 1995) and increases by the same amount the duty applying to policy by‐law items 47, 55, 57 and 60. The concessional rate of duty for the three policy by‐law items which are to be administered on a project basis (items 45, 46 and 56) will remain at `free', and the two policy by‐law items (items 43 and 52) relating to split consignments of whole goods unable to be transported on a single vessel or aircraft because of the size of the goods or because of an inadvertent delay in shipment will retain the duty rate currently applicable for the whole goods stock.

If this bill is not dealt with in these sittings, there will be a delay in the implementation of the measures which will cause a shortfall in revenue collected stock. This will have a significant impact on the government's budget deficit reduction program. Backdating implementation to 1 July 1996 in a later bill is not considered feasible.
The need for the amendments was not foreseen because the changes arose as a consequence of initiatives announced during the election campaign and developed since then.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja, I understand, expressed concerns that some of the non-government school funding may flow to wealthier non-government schools. Senator Stott Despoja should feel assured that that is not the intention. The $20.7 million for non-government schools capital is targeted to higher needs schools. Specifically, this additional assistance will provide assistance for technological advances in schools, about $17 million; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander support, $2.5 million; and hostels for rural students, $1 million. I can also assure the senator that the additional $20.7 million for non-government schools capital is just that—additional funding. It does not come at the expense of funding for government schools.

In relation to the query about Dr Kemp's announcement of more flexible funding for non-government schools, what I can say is that general recurrent grants for non-government schools under the policies of the previous government were purportedly based on financial need. However, there are now 25,000 students in non-government schools who have received less general recurrent funding than what they should have been entitled to had the Labor government not introduced its unfair and inequitable new schools funding arrangement in 1990.

Both Senator Carr and Senator Stott Despoja made some references to the government's proposed training wage under the MAATS proposal. I can assure senators in relation to the proposed industrial relation arrangements the government's take-home pay commitment is rock solid and will apply to trainees and apprentices. The existing award based apprenticeship and traineeship arrangements will continue. Employers can continue to choose to access them if they so wish. That includes the national training wage.

Under the proposed Australian workplace agreements, the amount of time spent in training will determine the amount of time for which the trainee is paid. That rate of pay will be the rate set out in the relevant award. The principle of paying trainees and apprentices for the time they spend in productive work is a sound one. In fact, Labor's national training wage is based on the principle that time spent in training is not paid for.

Senator Carr had some additional comments with respect to apprenticeship and traineeship numbers. He claimed that under Labor there was massive growth in apprenticeship numbers. While it is true that apprenticeship commencements increased in the 1980s, that is not the whole story because they then declined markedly in the early 1990s and have only recently increased again. In 1984‐85 there were just under 50,000 apprenticeship commencements. In 1994-95, 10 years later, there were still just under 50,000 apprenticeship commencements.

The government is committed to expanding opportunities for apprenticeship and traineeship arrangements, but increased flexibility and delivery arrangements to make sure that the training provided is relevant to workplace needs is essential. Employers can continue to choose existing apprenticeships and traineeships but they should also be able to take the opportunity for other models of work based training.

The government and many sectors of industry value highly the traditional apprenticeship model, but there is no need to be absolutely bound by it. We need to provide maximum variety and flexibility in training delivery to meet the needs of emerging industries and industries where the structured training effort has traditionally been quite low—the very areas where the training guarantee did not have significant impact.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Margetts, in her contribution, indicated that she opposed the abolition of the training guarantee. I think there is probably some agreement with respect to the government and opposition. The opposition introduced this when they were in government. We said it would not be as effective as they hoped it would be. The fact they abandoned it indicated that we were right in concluding that at the time. In conclusion, I thank sena tors for their sensible contributions they have made, albeit I have not necessarily agreed with all of them.
