SPEECH.PARA: We do support this bill, but not without some serious reservations about the current direction of the agreement. The direction, I might add, was well and truly put in place by the Labor government. Our main concern is that this agreement continues to slide away from a strong and solid commitment to public housing.

BREAK.PARA: Even though it may be in the guise of a commitment to `community housing', more rental assistance or a `broader range of options'—the rhetoric contained in this bill—the heart of the matter is that the previous government began a trend, which I think this coalition is continuing, away from building new public housing stock and away from providing public housing. It is all very well for the Australian Labor Party to sit in here and talk about how committed it was to the provision of public housing, but I am afraid that the facts speak for themselves.

Under the previous government, funds for public housing under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement fell by 40 per cent in real terms between the years 1986 and 1995. That is about $100 million which could have been spent on housing for Australians but was not. In the last six years of the Labor government, the number of new public housing units built fell by more than half, from 14,000 to 6,000. The number of families on public housing waiting lists blew out from 200,000 to more than 235,000. Not only that, in last year's budget the Labor government made a decision to cut rent assistance to low income families, a move that the Democrats opposed.

It is not just a question of funding. Every time the Labor government had a chance to increase the money levels available for public housing, it seemed to run away from that as fast as it could. For example, last year in this place my colleague Senator Spindler asked the government whether it would ensure that at least 10 per cent of the Australian Defence Industry site in the inner‐west of Melbourne was transferred to the Victorian government for public housing. That was an enormous site, with some 500,000 houses to be built on it. There is a chronic shortage of private and public rental housing in Melbourne's inner-west suburbs.

PARA.BREAK: But we did not see the then government rush to ensure that either five per cent or 10 per cent of the site was set aside for public housing. That is unfortunate. The government washed its hands of that matter and refused to do anything. Apparently, it would not even get on the phone and nicely suggest to the ADI, which is fully owned by the Common wealth, that they might consider that proposal. So we are a little wary when the Labor Party comes in here and talks about how committed they were to the provision of public housing, especially for low income earners.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that in this area—and in so many other areas—the previous government began a trend and handed to this government on a plate a system that is already depleted of funds, already run down and already close to breaking point. Emergency housing workers, local government social workers, family support workers and youth workers will tell you the same story of how they are unable to find housing for women who are trying to escape from domestic abuse. They will tell you stories of homeless families who are sleeping in shelters because they cannot afford the rent on the private market and cannot get into public housing. They will tell you about unemployed people, aged pensioners, people with disabilities and other low income earners who are struggling to pay the rent in substandard and overpriced private rental properties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gentlemen, could you either leave the chamber or sit down and not disturb Senator Stott Despoja.

Despite all the nice sounding rhetoric from this government, and the previous government, that is the trend that was begun by the ALP. I concur with Senator Faulkner's previous comments.

While I accept that the government needs to keep its budgetary options open, I find this is a bit ominous. It smacks of an intention to further pare back public housing assistance over subsequent financial years and of an unwillingness to commit to an ongoing and significant program of public housing. The other concern I have is that this government seems to think, as with the previous government, that it can boost housing choice for people on low incomes through the private rental market. That might look good on paper but it does not work in the real world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.

—I can't see how it makes much sense to throw subsidies, effectively lost money, at the private market when you could be building a better public housing asset base. It is one thing to involve the private sector in the planning and construction of public housing stock—that is appropriate and perhaps even desirable—but it is another thing altogether to use taxpayers' money to subsidise private involvement when you do not end up even owning stock. I remind the government that if we do not own the stock then not only are we not in a position to manage it appropriately and according to need but also we are not in a position to realise a gain, albeit a long‐term one, by selling some stock off over a period to low income earners.

BREAK.PARA: In short, the Democrats have been saying for some time that housing policy in this country continues to be both socially irresponsible and economically short‐sighted. TALK.START.PARA: —This housing bill is far from being non‐controversial. It is not just a technical bill; it is an important bill. It is a bill that is having significant implications for the public and for state governments. I believe it certainly was inappropriate for it to be brought up for lunchtime debate yesterday. SPEECH.PARA: This bill concerns the next Commonwealth-state housing agreement, CSHA, scheduled to start in about one month. It is not a simple addition to the existing act. It is actually a substantial change. It is also not identical to the bill that the last government proposed to establish a new CSHA. The bill was introduced into the House of Representatives only on 8 May—that is about three weeks ago. It was not introduced into the Senate until Wednesday of this week.

For the Greens (WA), the new CSHA is a significant event. It is to be, amongst other things, the agreement where public housing begins to take into account the social and environmental aspects of public housing implementation, and where conditions and benchmarks are set regarding these aspects.

Given that this bill was introduced on Wednesday and that there are substantial changes, it is not unreasonable to think that proper consideration of this bill can take place, firstly, so that it can be considered and reviewed correctly and, secondly, so that, if there is necessity for amendments to be moved, which we would like to see and table, then there is reasonable time for that process to take place. We were always going to be concerned about these things in this bill, no matter which government proposed the new CSHA. The fact that it is being proposed by a government that seems more preoccupied with gutting social support and overriding environmental considerations makes us more deeply concerned. The fact that this has been promoted as shifting the responsibility for public housing to the states is also a cause for concern.

I will not go into that issue too deeply at this stage, I will simply flag the fact that we intend to move a number of amendments to this bill in order to ensure that the social and environmental aspects of public housing are addressed and that funding transfers to the states are made conditional upon positive outcomes in these areas.

I take the time to make the point that public housing, and housing and urban design in general have an effect on our greenhouse performance. Urban design and building design and standards are often ignored in the greenhouse debate because they are difficult. Poor planning is very hard and expensive to remedy. Retrofitting and changing established urban forms is very expensive and very hard to get support for and agreement on. But doing something right at the planning stage is relatively easy.

In housing we are talking about physical objects meant to last decades. If we are going to make changes that are meant to last decades from now, this is the time to do the right thing and to do the thing which will end up saving us money in the long run. We pay for our mistakes for decades. Alternatively, we can reap the benefits of forethought and planning for decades. Costs may be direct—payment to build new power plants, roads, powerlines and schools—or they may be indirect, such as costs to the agricultural productivity due to climate change, costs to children of increased lead emissions from old cars driven from outlying suburbs, or costs to society of dislocation, alienation and the creation of welfare ghettos and the associated mind‐sets.

Future costs or future benefits?—that is what this bill is really about. Short-term bottom line thinking will create costs the beneficiaries of these programs will begin to pay from the time they move in. The costs to society may not fall due until a couple of years afterwards, although that is not necessarily the case. If we do have a commitment to public housing or a decent standard of housing, do we have a commitment to enable those people who occupy that housing to reduce their energy costs and to reduce the ongoing costs even to government if it gives assistance for things such as energy bills?

This bill will be important in the greenhouse debate. Public housing has been notably lacking in its attention to the principles promoted by government in energy efficiency. There are, however, some exceptions. In estimates processes in years gone by we have noticed that the Department of Defence is beginning to put standards of energy efficiency in its housing. It is looking at arid land gardens, at passive solar design and at ways of incorporating that into its housing design. What a good idea I thought. And, yes, I gave

BREAK.PARA: bouquets to Defence for doing that, even though I have problems with other aspects of its environmental program.

But doesn't it make you wonder why one department and not other departments are choosing to go along this road? The answer seems to be fairly clear. Defence get to keep their savings. The savings that are made as a result of the lower running costs of Defence housing are kept by Defence and used for other things; whereas other departments have to pay back those savings into general revenue or, if savings are accrued by state governments as a result of there being less cost in having to produce energy and so on, it is the state governments who gain that. So, unfortunately in our system, part of the problem of implementing good greenhouse policy is that those who implement the changes are not necessarily the ones who see the immediate benefits. This has to be changed and it has to be integrated through the system.

Houses are often not well insulated, and this greatly increases the costs of space heating or cooling. They are often poorly designed from a thermal standpoint. They usually fail to integrate things such as fluorescent lighting or solar hot water heating. They ignore issues such as water conservation. They do not necessarily have dual-flush toilets or water conserving showerheads. They ignore issues of solar orientation, window size, eave overhang and so on.

As we heard the other day in answer to a question about recycled paper—that is, `We'll only do it if the immediate costs are cheaper'—if the Commonwealth does not take the lead, how can we expect the rest of the community to follow? These are simple and often inexpensive things in the design and construction stage, but they are difficult and expensive to change in a built house. Failure to change them locks the tenants into either high energy use, and consequent high costs and high greenhouse emissions, or a life of misery—shivering through winter in unheated houses and roasting through summer in prefab ovens. Proper design and insulation can virtually eliminate the need for space heating and cooling.

We keep telling consumers, ordinary people, that greenhouse emissions are their responsibility. We advise them to use compact fluorescent light globes at $20 each, when an installation for an 18-inch fluorescent baton, plus a baton that is full solar spectrum and flicker‐free, costs only about $25. Afterwards, a replacement baton of a similar high quality costs about $5 to replace and lasts longer than a compact fluoro and is more energy efficient. Therefore, in building, we are making the wrong decisions. If such fluoros are designed in, they can provide soft diffused light. There is no need for the fluoro bar hanging in the kitchen any more than there is a need for the bare globe hanging from a chord. There are attractive inset fixtures.

We do virtually nothing for ordinary people who are trying to do their part for the planet. We actually make it difficult for them. It is fine to give a very small partial subsidy to people who are putting in a solar hot water system on the roof—which, when we questioned this matter further with the previous government, ended up to be a rather pathetic loan scheme at about normal loan rates—but it is still an expensive proposition. Poorer householders can do nothing.

Residents in rental housing are even worse off. They could not retrofit the house even if they could afford it. They have to cop the outcomes of the landlords economising in terms of power bills—cold uncomfortable winters and hot summers. This will either decrease quality of life markedly or entail an increase in costs borne by the renter. For poor people, especially the elderly or those with small children, poor heating in winter can have serious medical consequences. So-called environmental measures are often important social justice measures and measures to assure a reasonable quality of life at a reasonable cost.

I bring these things up in the context of this bill, because public housing is a major option for poor people. It is often the only way they will get affordable housing. If public housing does not include basic environmental design, then it is the government that penalises the poor. To date, on a number of occasions when I have asked these kinds of questions during Senate estimates, the kinds of answers I hear are, `But, Senator, you're talking about the environment; we're talking about economic development.'

Quite frankly, if you continue to separate housing and regional economic development you will find that there will be, amongst other things, an economic cost. But the reality is that any government which says that they have a commitment to equity, access and environmental standards should be incorporating these principles in each department. There should be environmental statements on or environmental assessments of any program changes so that we know what the impacts will be and whether there are spending changes or program changes.

As I mentioned, I have followed this area with interest in estimates committees and elsewhere. When I came here I discovered that the better cities program was a good program. It was advocating, demonstrating and spending hundreds of millions of dollars per year to promote energy efficiency and ecologically based urban restructuring; yet the billion or so dollars spent on public housing incorporates almost none of the principles promoted in the better cities program or in other programs.

When questions were asked about this, the reply was, `But it will cost too much.' There was very little, if any, information proffered by the departments about their looking for existing information on the actual cost of implementing those programs and the relatively short turnaround time in those programs paying for themselves—especially if you are talking about the cost to people who have no other choice but to live in those kinds of houses.

Programs were being operated in the same program area. Some of those programs were looking at energy efficient housing and the information was not being passed on to other departments. Believe me, there are copious reports around which give the information that is required. So it did seem to me that, in terms of public housing, there was very little effort being made to translate the benefits from good design and good planning into the actual program.

Certainly a lot of statements have been made about public housing. The last major Industry Commission report on public housing—of course, the Industry Commission is not necessarily known to be a body which has jumped on the bandwagon of welfare spending per se; generally they write reports which tend to favour their version of economic management and tend to favour large business—indicated that it was a very effective public spending program and deserved increased support.

Many of the reasons why this is effective have been given today. For example, it is important to give some access and equity considerations to the poorest in our society, to those who have very little choice left when we make decisions which impact, say, on the cost of petroleum. Those decisions impact on people who are being shoved out to the far suburbs and who have no other way of getting into shopping areas or places of employment except in a motor car. Basically we have to take those considerations into account when we design our cities.

In Western Australia pensioners are being moved out of prime areas like East Perth or North Fremantle. They are being sent to outer areas and those prime lands are being developed for the rich. Doing that seems to forget equity and access altogether and imposes these social costs onto the people who can least afford them. You cannot really do that. In my opinion you should not be doing that unless you already have a good public transport system, unless those people have access to the normal things they need in life—the ability to go to the shops, the ability to live a normal life, to access schools and so on.

So it is important that we take all of these issues into consideration when we are dealing with the issue of public housing. I reiterate the fact that I will be requesting at the end of this second reading contribution that, having had since all of Wednesday to look at the implications of this bill, it would be fair if we adjourned this portion of the debate so that we can carefully look at this important issue in the committee stage.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of history in this bill—a very interesting mix of history. We have a coalition government presenting a bill drafted by a Labor government to abolish a highly successful statutory authority set up by a previous coalition government. It makes one wonder where the consistent public policy might be in this bill other than in its history.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Commission was established 31 years ago when Robert Menzies was Prime Minister. It was established by a conservative government which identified a serious hole in the housing finance markets and decided that it was a good idea for the government to do something to fix it. That was back in the days when governments believed they had a role in people's lives. Robert Menzies' government believed that in the case of market failure the public sector should get in and fix it. But these days those kinds of actions appear quaint and unusual.

After 13 years of financial deregulation, our financial sector is still riddled with market failures, but we do not see Prime Minister John Howard saying, `I'll do a Menzies, my hero. I'll set out to fix this.' I think also these days both the Treasurer, Peter Costello, and the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, would probably cut their tongues out before they would follow the Menzies model and say that the government should set up its own financial corporation to assist low income earners.

The fact of the matter is: our financial sector is not functioning as a fully competitive, consumer friendly market. That is really quite clear. Fees are excessive and interest rates faced by housing and small business customers are still much higher than those faced by big business. There is no entirely effective consumer watchdog or arbiter of complaints. We have a banking code of practice, but it is one you could drive an armoured van through. Anyone who gets up and says these days, in 1996, that the government has a role in fixing it because the market is not actually working gets burned at the stake as a heretic.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was formed in 1965 to insure home lenders against losses secured by mortgages, principally housing loans. It was also specifically tasked with increasing home loan affordability for low and middle income earners who at the time faced expensive second mortgages to obtain loans with low deposits. It was the first insurer of its time and it proved to be very profitable. It is now basically self-financing and its repayments to the Commonwealth through dividends, special payments and taxation amount to $146 million—significantly more than the original capital injection.

The last two years have been very successful ones for the HLIC with 94,700 loans insured in 1994 and another 84,000 loans insured in 1995. Gross profits were $24.8 million in 1994 and $21.3 million in 1995 with $15 million in tax and $15.4 million in dividends being paid to the government. Despite the entry of other loan insurers into the market, the HLIC still insures about half of the loans insured in Australia.

This bill will corporatise the HLIC, moving the assets to a new company, HLIC Ltd. This new company will lose some of the competitive advantages and all of the public sector obligations of the current HLIC. It will compete in the market in a purely commercial manner.

When the government is a little more certain of the value of the company in a purely commercial market, we know that it is going to be sold for about $100 million. With that sale will once again go the potential of the government to have further influence on failures in the financial markets.

The Democrats oppose this bill. We oppose it because we believe the HLIC still has a significant public purpose to undertake. We oppose it because we do not accept that governments no longer have a role in dealing with market failure in the financial markets. We oppose it because we are not persuaded that the public sector will be better off selling the company and retiring debt than keeping the company and the profit stream. I am not even persuaded that the housing loans insurance market is fully competitive.

How does it work? Banks choose the insurer, but the housing customer pays the premium. The consumer does not even know whether the premium they are paying is the lowest possible one, because they are not allowed to shop around for it. The Democrats would prefer to see the scope of the HLIC expanded to deal with other financial market failures. The key market failure is the pricing of small business finance.

PARA.BREAK: I have said this before, and I would like to say it again: financial deregulation has so far largely failed to deliver any benefits to the small business community. The Reserve Bank estimates that small business loans are let at rates three to four per cent higher than big business loans. Small business operators complain, with some justification, that these premiums are unreasonable given the level of risk. They are particularly unreasonable given that virtually all banks insist on security for small business loans—usually the family home—and will not lend on the basis of cash flow. The Democrats have, for some time, supported the establishment of a loans insurance scheme for small business loans, particularly for small businesses with a bit of a commercial track record, which are not seeking to expand. This is something sensible and practical which the government could introduce to fix a major problem in our financial markets affecting their major con stituency. Yet last year the coalition supported the sale of the Commonwealth Development Bank, which could have provided such a service. Today what are we doing? We are setting in train the sale of the HLIC, which also could have done this. Our proposal is similar to the proposals put forward by the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures and by small business banking expert Anna Borzi for such a scheme. The very experience of the HLIC and of the Export Finance Insurance Commission shows that such schemes can work.

SPEECH.PARA: The market has not filled this gap. It will not fill this gap. I think that if Robert Menzies were alive today, he would be in there like a shot—like a true Liberal. It is a pity that his inheritors did not inherit a more liberal view of the role of government and the role of markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the opposition to support the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill. The bill is virtually identical to that presented by us when we were in government and passed by the House on 24 October. The bill lapsed in the Senate due to the election.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot has made a number of critical points, but I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate, and others who are listening, that the market has changed considerably since this corporation was established over 30 years ago. Since that time, other insurers have entered the mortgage insurance market, thereby reducing the necessity to maintain the corporation in public ownership. Senator Kernot has outlined a range of background material that, for the purposes of saving time, I am not going to repeat. I am sure Senator Gibson will refer to some of those matters.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was exempt from supervision by the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission—the ISC. Consequently, it did not have to comply with the capital adequacy arrangements applying to its competitors. To overcome a range of problems, the former government decided to abandon the privatisation option, but to restructure the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The corporation was re‐established as a company, incorporated under the companies law and subject to the regulatory requirements of the ISC, as well as those of the states and territories. The new company is fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the ISC, drawing on part of the present capital and reserves. The Commonwealth guarantee on borrowings for the new company will be removed; however, transitional arrangements will be implemented to allay uncertainty arising from the restructuring and to ensure the new company attains the appropriate credit rating required by state legislation without the need for further capital injections.

These arrangements will considerably improve the competitive neutrality of the mortgage insurance market, continuing the strong record of the former government in terms of achievements in the competition policy area. The transfer of the staff of the corporation to the new company will be achieved with the maintenance of existing conditions and entitlements such as leave, superannuation and workers compensation.

This bill represents good policy which simultaneously improves the competitive neutrality in the mortgage insurance market, improves Commonwealth finances by around $100 million and maintains the conditions and entitlements of the staff thereby guaranteeing industrial harmony during the restructuring process but lessening the contingent liabilities of the Commonwealth into the future. This represents another example of the good economic management of the former government. This bill is supported by the opposition in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We supported this proposal when it was raised by opposition when it was in government. Corporatisation of the HLIC is a good idea. There is no reason why it should not be operating as a fully commercial entity in a competitive marketplace. It is also important to note that the success of the HLIC over many years has helped to create a very competitive housing loan market in Australia. Consumers today are getting the benefits from that competitive market.

SPEECH.PARA: The securitisation of home mortgages and the cutting of interest rates has allowed the entry of new suppliers of home loans into the Australian market. Home buyers and people refinancing their homes have received definite benefits as a consequence. Securitisation of that industry could not have taken place without the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation's background of insuring mortgages.

New entrants into the housing loan industry insist that their mortgages be insured with the HLIC or another entity. Given the great benefit for all consumers in the housing market, there is absolutely no reason why the HLIC should remain tightly within the government's hold. The HLIC should be corporatised. Senator Sherry outlined the principle benefits of this proposal. It will become, under the Corporations Law, a corporatised entity at arms length from government and the government welcomes this move.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech read as follows—

The Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1996, which is before the Senate, deals primarily with the powers accorded the Commissioner of the AFP in relation to dismissing staff and members of the AFP. The powers being proposed go well beyond the present powers and have the potential to make significant changes to the job security of members of the AFP.
We contacted the AFP Police Association and were somewhat surprised to hear that the association supports the measures in the Bill.

The main provisions of the Bill concern removing the impediment to the Commissioner's power to remove an officer or staff member in cases of misconduct. Honourable Senators would be aware that, at present, the Commissioner must instigate internal disciplinary measures to remove someone from the AFP, even if that person has been convicted of a criminal offence by a court.

If that was the only impediment being removed, I could be happy with the change. However, the Bill, in Item 6 (new s26F) takes a further step which I cannot support, namely that the Commissioner will be able to remove from the AFP someone whom he or she believes is engaged in serious misconduct, whether or not charges have been laid, much less on the basis of a conviction.

The Bill then takes this power to remove a person from the AFP one step further still, in the form of excluding a person removed under s26F from taking action for wrongful dismissal under the Industrial Relations Act.

No doubt the government will argue that this leaves the person the option of taking action under the Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act or under common law. However, as senators would know, taking such a step is a vastly different, more complex and potentially more costly proposition than taking a wrongful dismissal matter through the Industrial Relations processes.

Furthermore, an action taken under the ADJR Act cannot only be on points of law—it can only be a review of whether due process took place in relation to the dismissal. It cannot be a review of the merits of the case.
That is why I was surprised that the AFP Police Association was supportive of the Bill—it significantly weakens the rights of members and staff of the AFP under certain circumstances.

Of course, these measures have been promoted on the basis of their usefulness in the fight against corruption—a laudable aim. However, even in matters of corruption, we dare not infringe on peoples' rights.
It seems to me that this issue involves the larger matter of accountability, and I want to say a few words about that.

`Accountability' has become something of a mantra in recent years, but the use of the word is all one way—accountability upwards, to the funding providers. We see this particularly in areas such as Aboriginal affairs, community sector organisations, health providers, aged care providers and the like. That is, those who are provided with government money have to record, report, account, and so on, for every cent and the way it is used. Woe betide the organisation that spends money for pens and pencils!!

But there is more to accountability. Accountability is also owed to those who are the recipients of services. It is owed to those who are employed. This is an accountability of service, an accounta bility about how an organisation performs its services and meets its commitments to clients and staff.

Staff are not simply a tool placed somewhere between the source of funds and the end point of the service. They are an integral part of an organisation and the organisation has as much a duty of accountability to them as to clients, (however they may be defined) and to those who provide the funds.

I am sure it is easy for the government, any government, to `sell' the idea of a crack down on corruption. Of course corruption should be fought wherever and whenever it occurs. But a society which claims to abide by the rule of law cannot simply sweep aside the rights of people, any people, under the rubric of fighting corruption or the mantra of accountability.

The Bill in its present form is insupportable. I will be putting amendments to the Senate in Committee in the hope of restoring what I regard as the fundamental rights of staff members and members of the AFP.

Specifically, those amendments would allow the Commissioner to remove from the AFP someone convicted of a criminal offence under the relevant regulations, but not someone who may be charged, or has been charged but not yet convicted. That would still leave the Commissioner the power to instigate internal disciplinary action.
I trust that there are sufficient senators who hold to the notion that people are innocent until proven guilty to gain support for my amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to speak about a petition which I was able to lodge with the Senate for over 17,000 people from New South Wales. I think honourable senators would appreciate that 17,000 people on one petition is an extraordinary number of people. In fact it took some time for me to lodge it because, first of all, it took a long time to count up the number of names and, secondly, it was not in the proper form. Unfortunately, I had to lodge the petition after the subject of the petition had already been reported on by the Senate, and I want to take the opportunity now to speak briefly about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The petition was made by petitioners from New South Wales who were concerned about the tobacco inquiry by the Senate community affairs committee. It was from small business people who were concerned by a recommendation made by that committee that the government, or governments, should consider ways in which the sale of cigarettes could be limited to people under the age of 18 and, in particular, whether or not there should be some restriction to licensed premises for the sale of cigarettes.

To give the Senate some background on this issue, the reason why I became involved is that the Philip Morris company wrote to everyone who sells cigarettes in New South Wales and implied—I think anyone reading their letter would have made this a reasonable implication—that I was in some way in favour of this proposal. They gave my name and address as the person to contact if people were somehow aggrieved by this and wished to register their complaint.

This was a spectacular piece of political stupidity on the part of the Philip Morris company, and I think it reflects very poorly on their corporate affairs department. Had they bothered to contact me prior to sending that letter out and using my name in that way, they would have found out that I had every intention of supporting the very thing that they were advocating.

When I became aware of this letter—and I became aware of it because of the hundreds of people who contacted my office—I rang Philip Morris and I asked, ` Can I have the list of the people you have sent this letter to so that I, too, can write to them and say that I agree with everything that you want to achieve from your letter. I want to write to those people to say that I will support their case in the Senate.' They refused to give me any names and addresses of the people they had sent it to. The only recourse I had was to the Yellow Pages business list. I was in the position where I had to write to every pizza joint, every petrol retailer, every newsagent—every small business in New South Wales—which sold cigarettes.

I think the response that I got to the petition which I enclosed in my letter would indicate to senators that there is a very strong feeling out there in the community, not just from small business people but from their customers, that any move to restrict the sale of cigarettes by targeting small businesses—such as newsagents, petrol stations and corner milk bars—is a very unfair way of achieving the very laudable aim which the committee was trying to achieve. It is another example of how small business can be made the victim when somebody wants to achieve some greater purpose in society.

The problem with the contention—I am not saying that the committee wanted to do this—that you should restrict the sale of cigarettes only to licensed premises or only to registered tobacconists is that small businesses, the corner shops, are not in a position where they can go to the expense of getting a special licence, nor can they generate the volume to justify it, whereas big business—major supermarkets and others—can quite easily afford that. The upshot of that proposition would be that the beneficiaries would be big business, and small business would suffer. Also, I do not think this would be any great advancement to the reduction of smoking by people under the age of 18.

BREAK.PARA: So it was a very ill-advised route that the committee decided to go down. But the committee certainly did not make any strong recommendation in this regard. The committee was well aware that the powers in this area do not lie with the Commonwealth government anyway; it is entirely a matter for the states to regulate.

To target the Senate and me, in particular—and I was not the only one; I think other honourable senators were targeted in other states—was a very devious thing for the Philip Morris company to do. It was certainly very unfair. But having representations from some 17,000 people—and it would be at least that because many other sheets of papers came in which we could not submit to the Senate—indicates the strength of feeling that small business people have, and I think it is very easy to see why.

The sorts of small businesses that I am talking about operate as convenience stores. They sell cigarettes because people drop in for cigarettes and buy other things such as milk, bread, newspapers, petrol and so on. These small businesses make their living as convenience stores. They work extraordinarily long hours because, only by working those hours, can they provide a service for people which is not otherwise available. They can truly claim to be some of the hardest working people in business in the Australian economy. The very fact that the nature of their work requires them to be at their place of work for as long as it does, and at all of the times when other Australians are out enjoying themselves, indicates just how dedicated to their business they are.

I was very pleased to present that petition. I very strongly believe that, where people want to serve a greater good in the community, then they should be sensitive to the effects that that will have. All of the people who signed that petition also said that they were strongly opposed to under 18‐year‐olds smoking and to the sale of cigarettes to people under the age of 18.

All of those small business people would be more than happy to support any move which did something about that particular problem. The fact that they were opposed to this particular recommendation and this particular measure should not be taken as some indication that they were either indifferent to the question of smoking by people under the age of 18 or that they somehow advocated it. I think that would be an unfair and wrong inference to make.
Again, this is my opportunity to bring the concerns of those 17,000‐odd petitioners to the Senate. I hope that in future the Senate will take those thoughts into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to comment on a recently tabled report from the Higher Education Council entitled `Equality, diversity and excellence: Advancing the national higher education equity framework '. This is an excellent report which evaluates the success of the higher education system in meeting the original equity objectives set out in the white paper of 1988. It provides advice on a policy framework to meet those equity objectives in the next five years.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition government should be making policy through evaluation and assessment of previous policy, and setting the goals which we want to reach in the higher education sector. However, what the government is doing now is in complete opposition to good practice in policy making. It is illogical. It does not look at the goals of the higher education sector. Instead, the approach is to slash and burn and to take any initiative which will push the higher education sector into private hands.

The policy goal of equity is absolutely intrinsic to Australia's universal right under citizenship to quality education. We need to look after our disadvantaged groups such as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, women, people from non-English speaking backgrounds, people with disabilities, rural and isolated students, and people from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds.

This report has found that, under the Dawkins model of mass education, the mass education approach has alleviated problems of access for some groups, at least numerically; namely, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, students from non-English speaking backgrounds and women in lower level courses. This success can be directly associated with special programs introduced during the last five years by the groups which have made them more flexible in their teaching assessments, admission requirements, support services and access programs, and which have gone some way to remove access barriers.

There are two major groups which have not been greatly assisted by these mechanisms in the areas of success and retention in higher education, and these are indigenous and isolated students. Also, the most underrepresented groups at universities are, again, isolated students and students from low socioeconomic backgrounds.

This report advocates more complex solutions to these problems which go to the heart of organisational culture and structures. Some of these recommendations include the prioritisation of equity in management structures, in corporate policies and in evaluating progress towards equity. Also important is effective understanding of the profile of the student body and a student centred approach to teaching and flexibility in practice to meet different student needs. Of course, these changes are not enough without additional funding of approximately $4 million for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, isolated and disabled students.

The government must urgently heed the knowledge of this document. Their slash and burn cuts will destroy the present equity gains in the sector and destroy the formation of a future equity program which looks at the deeper structural reasons for inequity. This is what the higher education sector must now turn its attention to to address.

This report rightly claims that inequality of representation in education is the result of multiple social, educational and economic factors, which are not due to different overall levels of ability. Yet the government is pursuing a path of decreasing student numbers, concentrating research and curriculum strengths in certain universities and not others under the double‐speak term of `diversity', which actually reduces it.

BREAK.PARA: The government is embarking on a program of fees for all postgraduate students and substantially increasing HECS rates and possible undergraduate fees. These will hit the poorest students the hardest. This socioeconomically disadvantaged group is already the most underrepresented group in the university system along with isolated students. Again we will see the return to the pre-Whitlam days of education for the privileged, and access and equity will go out the window. Then no amount of support services or changed management practices will help because the primary barriers will be financial. The Liberal's solution will be scholarships, but these only help the brightest of the poor.

As this report points out, the ability to succeed at university is less about intelligence, some sense of innate ability or potential, and more to do with economic, social, educational and circumstantial factors. The Greens believe the coalition government's proposed changes to higher education go to the heart of preserving these structural inequalities and therefore perpetuate inequality of access and participation at university. The fact that programs which have worked on increasing the participation rate of some sectors of the community which traditionally have been underrepresented in the university sector are having success is not—and I stress the word not—a reason to remove them.

I know of a case where we had groups of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tertiary students visiting us, and they indicated that they certainly have a participation rate which is increasing. It has taken a long time to get that increase in the participation rate, but to have the retention rate for students to get through the courses will take a lot more.

There is also a lot of catching up to do. Let's face it. If what we are seeing is more confident and older people, for instance, in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities now coming to achieve their potential so that they can work in their communities. It makes absolutely no sense whatsoever to cut out the special support programs so that the younger people in the community will not be able to follow on. If anybody thinks that those support services are not required, they have not talked to the groups involved and they have no understanding of the issues involved.

The Greens would like to see this significant and insightful report's recommendations taken up by the government. Some of these important recommendations include separate equity planning responses to each of the different disadvantaged groups, putting student profiles to the equity test, changing the basis of institutional equity plans, performance based equity funding, and priority initiatives for socioeconomically disadvantaged and isolated students.

If these recommendations are to work, it must be in a context in which the government preserves the current gains in equity made for women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students and students from non-English speaking backgrounds. If not, then equity will take a backward step and Australia will progress faster to a higher education system for the privileged.

SPEECH.PARA: Since then there have been a number of initiatives by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. My party, my party leader—the honourable member for Brand (Mr Beazley)—and I agree with the initiatives to remove these horrible weapons from our society. Hopefully those bills will get through the parliament with speedy passage with the support of every parliamentarian in this place. I believe that will be for the good of our society.

I would hope, though, that that is only a start. I want to get back to a theme I have raised in this place before: the removal of guns from our society per se; remove them all. Our police could also take the initiative. I know that in the police force in my state, Western Australia, police can make the choice as to whether or not they wear guns. The majority, unfortunately, choose to wear them. I do not think there is a call for that in Australian society or in Western Australian society.

It appals me when I see a policeman in a local shopping centre marking identification marks on children's bicycles and he has a gun strapped to his hip. There is no need for that. It is a macho thing that ought to be done away with. Hopefully, with all these guns removed from our society, the police in turn will also see the need not to have them.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as you get them off the criminals as well.

—Yes, get them off the criminals as well. But where does it start, Senator Panizza? If you were a criminal and you know the cops are going to be armed, you would be armed. I am not saying to remove all guns from the police. But I am saying that I do not see the need for a policeman on traffic patrol duty—doing what they are employed to do it would seem; collecting revenue from speeding motorists, rather than doing the more important things—to have a gun strapped to their hip. I really do not see the need for that. Perhaps the various state authorities can use the revenue saved for other purposes.

BREAK.PARA: I now take this opportunity to congratulate the government on their election. This is the first opportunity I have had to congratulate them. It was a victory which nobody can walk away from. I must say that it was more comfortable sitting on the benches opposite than it is sitting over here, although today I got some delight from watching some of the antics in the performances by people on the opposite side when they were trying to responsibly get legislation passed.

I noted that Senator Hill took up my interjection about offering the resignation of Senator Kemp to see whether that could speed up the passage of legislation. He unfortunately did not pick up my interjection about offering Senator Panizza's head as well. I am certain that, had he done that, our Green colleagues would have picked up the offer and we would have moved on and allowed the bills to pass.

The election was a very strong victory for the Liberal Party. It was not a victory for the National Party in Western Australia, but it certainly was a victory for the Liberal Party right throughout Australia. But it was not a complete rout. The coalition government, including the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and all his ministers, will have to remember the election promises they were elected upon. They cannot run away from them all.
I have a sign in my window which is attracting quite a deal of comment from people wondering why I have John Howard's picture in my office window. Why do I have that there? It is to remind you—

TALK.START.PARA: —You want Stevenage.

—No, John Howard wants Stevenage—not me. `I want Paul Stevenage', the sign says. It has a picture of John Howard and Paul Stevenage on it. Paul Stevenage was the Liberal Party candidate in the seat of Moore, which was ultimately won by the Independent Paul Filing, a former Liberal Party member. It must not be forgotten—I do not let Paul Filing forget this—that he was elected on Paul Stevenage's preferences. Mr Stevenage is challenging in the High Court Mr Filing's election. I mention this issue because a number of things happened during that campaign—a very bitter campaign not between the main political parties but between the—
—But they are internal matters.

—These are not internal matters, Senator Panizza, when in the early hours of the morning some elderly people were threatened by young Liberal thugs. That was not orderly at all. There were a number of other instances like that which should not have been allowed to happen during an election campaign. I certainly would not condone it in my party.

BREAK.PARA: The other very interesting election campaign—I thought I might have had an interjection about it—was that in Kalgoorlie, where a former Labor Party member stood for election. He was contested by another good friend of mine, Ian Taylor, on behalf of the Labor Party and another friend of mine, Cedric Wyatt, a former left wing Labor Party member but the endorsed Liberal Party candidate. Politics is a complex thing.

It was a difficult campaign for people like me who knew all the individuals in it. History now records that Mr Campbell won the contest. I do have a regret, though, about Cedric and how he was used in the campaign. He is a very nice individual. Unfortunately, he made the wrong choice in going over to the Liberal Party. He should have been given more resources and more help in the campaign than he was given. That is unfortunate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, a good effort was made.
—A pretty appalling effort was made, actually. There was very little Liberal Party presence during that whole campaign. I can understand that at times you put a bigger effort in than at other times—
—Come on! That's wrong. I can give you the names of five senators who helped him.
—Give me the itineraries of the senators who helped—in fact, table them, Senator Panizza.

BREAK.PARA: The final comment I wish to make in the minute or so I have left to speak is to say a formal farewell to our Senate colleagues whom I will not be involved in parliamentary sittings with again: Senators Beahan, Crichton-Browne, Chamarette, Jones, Burns, Wheelwright, Bell, Spindler and Teague. There are nine in total; I think I have mentioned every one of them. I am not going to comment about each and every one of them other than to say that in the vast majority of cases I have thoroughly enjoyed their company, including when participating in committee hearings. I think I have worked with Senator Spindler a great deal more than I have worked with any of the senators who are retiring.

I take this opportunity to wish each and every one of them all the very best for their future. I ask them to pass on those wishes to their families. Let us hope that their lives become somewhat easier in retirement than perhaps they were when they were serving parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of foreshadowed cuts to all levels of education, the report of the Bureau of Industry Economics on the future of the multifunction polis makes very interesting reading. It recommends that further funding to the MFP site be terminated. Perhaps this offers us one way of ameliorating to some degree the plight that higher education and research institutions are in at the moment.

The MFP was hatched in 1987 by the Japanese government with the assistance of former Senator Button. The previous Labor government had cut funding to universities and to research institutes such as the CSIRO, and yet vigorously promoted the fairyland idea of a multifunction polis as a leader in the development of international science and technology. From the very beginning, this proposal came under trenchant criticism from the Australian Democrats and a number of key academics. One of the principal grounds for this criticism was that the MFP was taking resources that should have been spent on both basic and applied research within Australian universities and research institutes.

From the beginning, the MFP was a fairyland, and any suggestion to this effect to government ministers at the time by the Australian Democrats was met with derision. The former government maintained at the beginning that no government funding would be spent on the multifunction polis; it was to be privately driven. But, for nine years, both the federal and the South Australian governments have poured money into what can only be described as a face‐saving exercise.

In the early years, the federal government maintained that the MFP would be the largest development ever undertaken in this country and that, by concentrating resources into the MFP, this facility would lead Australian industry and the Australian economy out of the valley of desolation and destruction that the government had taken it into. At this time, I might add, many opposition senators thought that the MFP was a mirage. Unfortunately, they did not support attempts by my predecessor, Senator John Coulter, when he moved amendments in appropriation debates in November 1991 that the roughly $4 million allocated by the government in that budget to the MFP be removed. His motion was not supported by the opposition.

In its original MFP concept document, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry included a proposal to build a 2.1 kilometre high mountain with a runway for launching linear rocket vehicles into orbit. Both federal and state governments—the South Australian government—have spent considerable sums trying to convince the public that the always ill‐defined MFP was a profitable and productive way to spend the public's taxes. It held expensive conferences costing $1,000 for two days. The Bannon government spent $150,000 on a public relations firm to convince South Australians and other taxpayers and more recently retained a chief executive at $370,000 a year salary and bonuses, all as part of the promotional tour for the MFP.

It is really remarkable how unwilling governments, politicians and many bureaucrats are to admit that they have made a mistake and how a lot of this public money has in fact been spent defending the indefensible. Nor has the practice stopped. In the last few years, two projects have been promoted as achievements of the multifunction polis—the cleaning up of the polluted Gillman site and the building of a group of energy efficient and novel energy technology‐using houses at Northaven. They have been claimed to be successes; in fact, the former was a success but it did not need the expensive backing of the MFP.

Several university departments, together with soil engineers and a few earthmovers would have had the same effect more cheaply. As to the two houses at Northaven, it is clear that these continue the practice of public window dressing and not a serious attempt to address the urgent need to develop more energy efficient housing for Australian conditions.

Firstly, the houses were not built by the MFP, but by a private builder. Not one has eaves to protect the walls from heat gain or loss, and solar water heating is absent. One house has a geothermal heating and cooling system, that is, one that circulates water through a pipe deep underground and, inside the house, uses this constant temperature water as a heat sink for a reverse cycle refrigeration system to heat and cool the house. I will explain that later, Senator Panizza, if you wish.

BREAK.PARA: This system is unusual in Australia and may not hold promise of more energy and cost efficient housing. To find out, it would be necessary to monitor for over a year or more every aspect of the energetics and economics of the system. But no monitoring equipment has been fitted into this unit. It is window‐dressing for the uninformed and uninitiated.

Finally, in the forthcoming year it is expected that the federal government will spend some $4 million on the MFP and the state government will spend about $24 million. In light of the report by the Bureau of Industry Economics recommending that funding to the MFP should be terminated, and in light of the failure of the MFP to deliver any of its promised benefits, it is time for the government to recognise the mistakes that have been made, by its predecessor admittedly, and to divert any funding which might otherwise have gone to the MFP to our universities and
to the CSIRO, which can deliver on research and development in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism upon notice, on 7 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of the Cooperative Research Centres (CRCs) are government funded and privately funded.
(2) Can private and/or industry funding of CRCs be tax deductible; if so, how.
(3) Does the 150 per cent research and development tax deduction cover private and industry funding or donations to CRCs.

(4) Of the 150 per cent tax deductions given for research and development in the 1993‐94, 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years, what percentage and amount of money went for CRC‐related research and development.
(5) Which are the biggest companies to receive deductions for funding of CRC‐related research and development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the follow ing answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All CRCs receive government funding through the CRC Program. All CRCs involve other participants which vary from Centre to Centre but generally include CSIRO, universities, industry and federal and state government agencies. Industry has committed $401 million to the established sixty one CRCs over their funding periods.
(2) Please refer to paragraphs 5.2.12 and 5.2.13 of the CRC Program Guidelines for Applicants 1996 Round and General Principles for Centre Operations .
